translated: Birth Stories
The Group of Sixes
The Chapter with Short Stories
The Birth Story of Siṅghapuppha
“This water lily flower
that you’re sniffing without permission,🔽is one of the forms of theft.
You’re stealing the scent, my good man.”
“I’m not taking it or breaking it.
I’m just sniffing the water lily.
But for what reason
am I said to be stealing the scent?
“The one who digs up the roots
and breaks the lotuses,
he’s the one with a full schedule.
Why isn’t he said to be stealing?”
“The person who’s full of greed
is smeared with the dye of the cloth-maker.
I have nothing to say about him,
but I deserve to be spoken to.
For the person who’s free of corruption,
who always seeks purity,
even a hair’s tip of evil
appears as big as a cloud.”
“Surely you know me, spirit,
and you have compassion for me.
Again, spirit, you should speak
when you see someone like me.”
“I don’t live off you,
nor do I want to be your servant.
You, monk, should know
how to go to a good rebirth.”
The Story of Siṅghapuppha.
